anonymised: I think part of the issue is that we don't live in an age any more where whether you are working class or middle class is a very clear cut and obvious thing. Fifty years ago you could have told by someone's dress, address, and job title. now, not so much. Being 'working class' no longer means you're going down the pit each day, and being middle class no longer means having a house in the suburbs and going to work in a suit, so it's no surprise that class has become less solidly defined and more about self perception.
edited: I think part of the issue is that we don't live in an age any more where whether you are working class or middle class is a very clear cut and obvious thing.
